body:
[Visiting Assistant Professor](http://www.quantitative.emory.edu/about/ourfaculty/faculty%20/jacobson-jeremy.html) \
The Institute for Quantitative Theory and Methods\
Emory University    

### Publications and preprints

- Jacobson, J., [Real cohomology and the powers of the fundamental ideal](https://github.com/jeremyallenjacobson/jeremyallenjacobson.github.io/blob/master/RealCohomologyAndPowersOfFundamentalIdeal.pdf) (to appear), Annals of K-Theory.
- Jacobson, J., [Cohomological invariants of quadratic forms over local rings](https://github.com/jeremyallenjacobson/jeremyallenjacobson.github.io/blob/master/CohomologicalInvariants.pdf) (under review), Mathematische Annalen.
- Jacobson, J., [From the global signature to higher signatures](https://github.com/jeremyallenjacobson/jeremyallenjacobson.github.io/blob/master/GlobalSignature.pdf) (preprint).
- Jacobson, J., [Finiteness theorems for the shifted Witt and higher Grothendieck-Witt groups of arithmetic schemes](https://github.com/jeremyallenjacobson/jeremyallenjacobson.github.io/blob/master/Finitenesstheorems.pdf), Journal of Algebra, 351, pp. 254 - 278, 2012.
- Jacobson, J., [On the Witt groups of schemes](https://github.com/jeremyallenjacobson/jeremyallenjacobson.github.io/blob/master/Thesis.pdf), PhD Thesis at Louisiana State University, 2012.

### Teaching
- QTM 100: Introduction to Statistical Inference
- QTM 120: Math for Quantitative Sciences
- QTM 210: Probability & Statistics

## About me
I completed my PhD in Mathematics at Louisiana State University in 2012. During my PhD, I spent a year at the Mathematical Institute of the University of Bonn, Germany,  and two years visiting the Warwick Mathematics Institute, UK. Previous to joining the Institute for Quantitative Theory and Methods, I was a Visiting Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at Emory University. Prior to joining Emory, I taught at the University of Georgia and was a Fields Postdoctoral Fellow at the Fields Institute, Canada.

### (@jeremyallenjacobson)
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
